Authors:
Min Zhong, Benjamin Hansen, Maximilian P. Nesnidal, Anja
Golombek, Kenneth M. Halanych, Torsten Hugo Struck
Title:
Escaping the Symplesiomorphy Trap: A Multigene Phylogenetic
Analysis for Terebelliform Annelids.
Keywords:
Terebelliformia; Annelida; Mitochondrial Genome;
Phylogeny; Symplesiomorphy Trap; Incongruence; Skews; RCFV
Abstract:
For phylogenetic reconstructions, conflict in signal is
known to be a potential problem for tree reconstruction. For instance,
signal in molecular data from different cellular components, such as
mitochondrion and nucleus, may be inconsistent. Mammalian studies
provide one such case of conflict where mitochondrial data, which
display compositional biases, support the Marsupionta hypothesis, but
nuclear data confirm the Theria hypothesis. Most observations of
compositional biases in tree reconstruction have focused on the lineages
with the ‘unusual’ composition. However in some situations, the position
of related taxa that lack compositional bias may be influenced due to
apparent symplesiomorphic characters, a situation known as “the
symplesiomorphy trap”. Herein, we report an example of the
sympleisomorphy trap and how to detect it. Terebelliformia worms are
mainly tube-dwelling annelids comprising five ‘families’: Alvinellidae,
Ampharetidae, Terebellidae, Trichobranchidae and Pectinariidae. Using
mitochondrial genomic, as well as nuclear 18S and 28S rDNA and
elongation factor-1α, we revealed incongruence between mitochondrial and
nuclear data regarding placement of Trichobranchidae. Mitochondrial data
favored a sister relationship between Terebellidae and Trichobranchidae,
but nuclear data placed Trichobranchidae as sister to an
Ampharetidae/Alvinellidae clade. Additional investigations revealed that
mitochondrial data of Ampharetidae and Alvinellidae exhibited strong
compositional biases misplacing Trichobranchidae, rather than
Alvinellidae and Ampharetidae. Thus, Trichobranchidae was apparently
caught in the symplesiomorphy trap.
